story: NewsGrieving mum shares devastating photo of daughters coffin in bid for NHS law changeMum-of-two Angela Bain is now campaigning for Amys Rule, a process to support patients and carers to raise concernsa patients health condition is getting worseShareCommentsByKim Reader:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsAmy Lornie died aged five in September  " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A grieving mum has shared a devastating image of her daughteraposs coffin in a desperate bid for an NHS law change.Mum-of-two Angela Bain, , is campaigning to enable families to escalate their concernsthey feel their loved ones are not receiving proper care after the death of her little girl Amy Lornie. She believes hospital medics aposignoredapos her pleas and failed to diagnose the five-year-oldaposs deadly brain tumour.Amy was just four when she fell ill in April  and visited doctors with vomiting, weight loss, headaches, lethargy, clumsiness and out-of-character mood swings.However it was five months before the youngster was scheduled for an MRI on August , the mum says. Angela claims that instead of conducting the scheduled MRI, medics left Amy screaming and writhing around in agony in her hospital bed for around nine hours. She says nurses repeatedly dismissed her concerns about her daughteraposs aposdeterioratingapos condition, instead giving Amy paracetamol that aposdid nothingapos to ease her suffering. When one nurse allegedly responded to Angelaaposs plea for help by askingAmy had missed her nap time and might just be tired, the mum demanded to see a doctor. But when Angela got back to her daughteraposs bedside, she says Amyaposs body was completely limp as she had stopped breathing - and the little girl would never wake up again. Doctors and nurses got Amy breathing again and rushed her for an MRI which revealed a large brain tumour and bleed on the brain. Despite emergency surgeries to relieve the pressure on Amyaposs brain and remove the tumour, Angela says it was too late for her daughter whose brain stem was apossquashedapos during the bleed. Angela also claims doctors who removed the tumour told her that Amy would have had an % chance of surviving with cancer treatment. After weeks hoping Amy would wake up to begin chemotherapy, the family made the heartbreaking decision to take the little girl off her le support and she died days later in Angelaaposs arms. The mum believesher concerns about Amyaposs worsening condition had been listened to, her daughter would still be alive. She is now campaigning for aposAmyaposs Ruleapos to be enforced.  Angela, of Aberdeen, Scotland, said: I was back and forth finding doctors, nurses, anybody because Amy was rolling around in bed absolutely screaming in pain. I was going crazy for somebody to listen. Iaposm normally a nice person, I donapost raise my voice. But I was angry, I was shouting, I was swearing. It was so frustrating. I knew something wasnapost right. They kept saying they would give her paracetamol but that wasnapost doing anything for her pain. It was horrible watching her suffer like that. Around pm I went to the nurse and told her Amy was deteriorating right in front of my eyes and she asked meAmy was tired because sheaposd missed her nap time. Amy was five, she hadnapost had nap time for a long time. I told the nurse I needed to speak to a doctor. When I got back to Amy, her body was just floppy. Sheaposd stopped breathing. After they rushed her away I remember thinking aposwhy did no one listen to meapos. I really didnapost recognise myself that night, I was so angry. She never woke up again after she stopped breathing. The last moments that Amy was Amy were just pure pain roaring out of her. Those are my last memories of her. I feel like I canapost really remember her voice, all I can remember is her screams. The surgeons got a really really sick little girl and did their best to try to fix her but it was too late. In reality she was gone before she even got to them. Her brain stem has been completely squashed. It was flat as a pancake.  aposHappyapos little girl Amy, who was aposfull of leapos and loved to sing and dance, first fell ill in April  when she became unable to keep food down due to bouts of aposviolentapos vomiting. Over the next five months, Amy visited her GP and out of hours hospital doctors several times - always with the same symptoms of sickness, loss of appetite, tiredness, headaches, clumsiness and mood swings. At first Amy was treated for a viral infection, then a urinary tract infection, then reflux and even referred to a dietician with possible food intolerances but nothing was helping. Mum Angela and her partner Ross Lowe, , watched in despair as Amyaposs weight plummeted, going from wearing clothes for five-year-olds to those for three-year-old. Some months all Amy could stomach was a teaspoon of water every five minutes, given to her night and day by Angela and Ross just to keep the little girl hydrated enough. When her daughter took a particularly bad turn on August  - just two weeks after her fth birthday - Angela took Amy to Royal Aberdeen Childrenaposs Hospital. Angela claims hospital nurses carried out tests, raising concerns about Amyaposs problems balancing and that one of her eyes appeared to be larger than the other. The mum-of-two says Amy was scheduled to have an MRI at the hospital the next day at pm but this didnapost happen until after pm when Amy stopped breathing. Amy was then taken for emergency surgery to put a shunt in her brain to relieve some of the pressure before she could be flown to Edinburghaposs Royal Hospital for Sick Children on August . In Edinburgh, surgeons were able to remove the entire tumour from Amyaposs brain and the mass was found to be a cancerous medulloblastoma growth. The oncologist allegedly told Angela that with radiotherapy and chemotherapy, Amy would have an % chance of beating the cancer completely and surviving. With newfound hope, the little girlaposs family waited for weeks for her to wake up for treatment but Amy never opened her eyes again.  Angela said: Amy was a happy little girl, everybody loved her. She was amazing. She was a natural performer and loved to sing and dance. She was obsessed with Cats the musical. She was just so full of le and then bang - she wasnapost anymore. The surgeons in Edinburgh couldnapost have done any more. When they managed to remove the whole tumour, it gave us a sense of hope. Thataposs what doctors do, they fix people. It was a huge shock to find out Amy had cancer. I knew something was really wrong for months but I never expected that. It was just unreal. It was like it wasnapost happening to me. It was like I was standing back watching somebody aposs le. But the oncologist was really hopeful. He told us Amy had an % chance of survival with treatment. She just needed to be awake for the treatment. As time went on and she wasnapost coming around, I realised there wasnapost going to be a happy ending. We know now that her brain stem was pretty much dead from the pressure of the tumour and the bleed. And the brain stem doesnapost regenerate. If she had just got to Edinburgh sooner,Aberdeen had done the MRI they scheduled,someone had listened to me when Amy was in pain, she would have survived. It all comes down to her diagnosis not being fast enough because thereaposs a complete lack of awareness of the symptoms of brain tumours in children. Itaposs not fair, she should still be here. She didnapost even get the chance to fight and she had a lot of fight to give. A medulloblastoma PNET is a malignanttumour formed from primitive or poorly developed brain cells, according to the NHS. Less than  children a year develop medulloblastoma in the UK. However, it is still the most common malignant brain tumour in children, representing % of all childhood brain tumours. They are most common in children between the ages of three and eight, and are slightly more common in boys than girls. Symptoms include: nausea and vomiting , lethargy and irritability, headaches, clumsiness, dficulty with tasks like handwriting, gradual decline in school work, changes in personality and behaviour and abnormal gait. After being informed that Amy would only live for three months without cancer treatment, her family made the heartbreaking decision to take her off le support. Amy was transferred to Rachel House Childrenaposs Hospice in Kinross where she took her last breath on September  while in her mumaposs arms. The family held a funeral on October  and Amy was buried in a white cat costume to honour her love for Cats the musical. Her tragic death has had a devastating impact on Amyaposs family with Angela still struggling to process what has happened. And Amyaposs big sister Melissa Lornie, eight, wants nothing more than to see her sibling again. Angela said: Taking Amy off le support was the hardest decision but we knew she was going to die anyway. I was lying on the bed and Amy was lying on me with her head on my chest when she took her last breath. It was really peaceful. There was no struggling. It sounded like a really contented sigh when youaposre sleepy. And then she didnapost breathe again. I think she was waiting for it to just be me and her. We hadnapost been alone for so long, there were always doctors and nurses and family but as soon as we were alone she took her last breath. To this moment, I donapost think I have fully processed whataposs happened. I know sheaposs gone because she died on me but at random points in the day it hits me again. Itaposs like I have been totally paralysed. Getting up in the mornings is hard but I have to for Melissa. When Amy died a part of me died too. Melissa is really not good, she misses her sister. None of us like being in our house anymore. Itaposs like being trapped. There are so many bad memories.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA happy-go-lucky -year-old tragically died after taking a mixture of illegal drugs and alcohol at a house party, an inquest has heard. Andrea Horvathova was found unconscious at a property in Mutley, Plymouth, on the evening of Sunday March , . The hearing was told her boyfriend suggested she had taken a couple of lines of speed, a couple of lines of MDMA, and maybe ketamine, along with spiced rum. Senior coroner Ian Arrow noted the cause of death was given as sudden cardiac death brought on by her response to multiple drugs being consumed. He concluded he would record a verdict of drug related death. Police had also been called to the address after a group of people were reported to be under the influence of drink and controlled drugs, Plymouth Live reports. Andrea and another woman were both suffering the effects and raced to Derrord Hospital. The other woman survived, but Andrea died three days later on March , aged just . An inquest, presided over by senior coroner Ian Arrow noted how she had amphetamine, alcohol, Ecstasy, cocaine and a potent designer drug nicknamed Flakka in her system. Flakka - also known as Alpha PVP, or alpha-Pyrrolidinopentiophenone - is a stimulant that has had catastrophic effects on some communities in the United States. Plymouth Coroners Court heard a pathologistaposs toxicology report found Andreaaposs heart and liver had been damaged. The combination of drugs would have very likely resulted in a heart attack, the court heard. She had no physical injuries on her body. A statement from a close friend of Andreaaposs was read to the court.  She said she had known Andrea for two years and they regularly went to social events.She said Andrea, who was born in the Czech Republic, had revealed she had grown up in a care home and in June  had met a man called Alex whom she had a relationship with and had talked about going travelling with. The statement noted how Andrea and Alex had taken drugs together, but after their relationship ended Andrea began to take even more drugs, adding: she was upset by the end of the relationship. Her friend said Andrea worked in a factory and took le to the max and loved parties, saying up late, drinking and partying. She described Andrea as happy-go-lucky strong and independent woman. However, she then began another relationship with another man, who she lived with. At .pm on March  Andrea had emailed her friend askingshe could come around to visit. The pair later attended a small gathering at a house where Andrea began drinking.

title: harry dunns family say relationship
story: NewsHarry Dunn’s family say relationship with US has seen one of its darkest daysHarry Dunns furious family say they remain determined to win justice after the US announced it had rejected an extradition request for his alleged killer Anne SacoolasShareByLouie SmithBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  JAN NewsHarry Dunn died following a crash " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHarry Dunn’s family say the special relationship has seen “one of the darkest days” after the US rejected an extradition request for his alleged killer. The -year-old motorcyclist died following a crash with diplomat’s we Anne Sacoolas, , outside a US intel base on British soil. Earlier this month the Home Office applied for the mum-of-three to be extradited to face a charge of death by dangerous driving. But it has now been announced that US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has turned down the request. Harry’s furious family say they remain determined to win justice, eventhat means waiting for the “corrupt” Trump administration to fall from power.  Family spokesman Radd Seiger said: “That’s the first time in history that the United States has turned down an extradition request. “It’s one of the darkest days in the history of this special relationship. “It’s a completely indefensible decision both legally and morally. “The reality is that this administration, which we say is behaving lawlessly and taking a wrecking ball to one of the greatest alliances in the world, won’t be around forever whereas that extradition request will be. “We will simply plot and plan for a reasonable administration to come in one day and to reverse this decision.”  Harry died last August after a head-on crash with Sacoolas near RAF Croughton, Northants. The base has been loaned to the US for decades and it is understood her husband worked there. Sacoolas initially cooperated with police but left the country weeks later citing diplomatic immunity. Harry’s parents Charlotte Charles, , and Tim Dunn, , travelled to America in a bid to persuade her toto the UK.  But despite meeting Trump in the White House they were unsuccessful.Last week Prime Minister Boris Johnson described the chances of Sacoolas ever ing to the UK as “very low”.Mr Seiger said the comments - made after an extradition request was submitted - had done “real damage” to their campaign. The US State Department announced their rejection late on Thursday night. A spokesperson said: “If the United States were to grant the UK’s extradition request, it would render the invocation of diplomatic immunity a practical nullity and would set an extraordinarily troubling precedent.”

title: prince charles gets rock stars
story: NewsPrince Charles gets rock stars welcome as hes mobbed in streets of BethlehemPrince Charles braved the crowds as he began his first visit to the West Bank and also made a personal pilgrimage to the exact spot where Christians believe Jesus Christ was bornShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThe Prince got a rock stars welcome " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPrince Charles received a rock star’s welcome as he was mobbed through the streets of Bethlehem on his first visit to the West Bank.  Amid chaotic scenes, the Prince of Wales braved the crowds and the howling rain to deliver a message of peace and unity by meeting Muslim and Christian leaders. In the historic Manger Square, the heir entered the Mosque of Omar, the only mosque in the Old City of Bethlehem, before signing his name in Arabic in the visitors’ book to the delight of his hosts.  A while later he made the short walk across the way, to make a personal pilgrimage to the exact spot where Christians believe Jesus Christ was born, in the crypt of the Church of the Nativity.  Charles was universally praised by religious leaders from several faiths who came together for his historic visit, saying the heir was responsible for “giving hope to all Christians”. The Prince has been a long term supporter in multi-faith dialogue and said he had always strived to bring people together.  Speaking at a reception in Bethlehem celebrating the ties between British and Palestinian people, the prince said it was his wish that “a just and lasting peace” would be established for all peoples in the region. He said: “Throughout my le, I have tried, in whatever very small way I can, to foster greater understanding between people of dferent faiths, to heal isions and to remind people of so much that we share in common as opposed to what ides us. Elsewhere in the world too, I have endeavoured to build bridges between dferent religions so that we might learn from each other and be stronger together as a result. It breaks my heart therefore that we should continue to see so much suffering and ision.  No-one arriving in Bethlehem today could miss the signs of continued hardship and the situation you face. And I can only join you, and all communities, in your prayers for a just and lasting peace. We must pursue this cause with faith and determination, striving to heal the wounds which have caused such pain. It is my dearest wish that the future will bring freedom, justice and equality to all Palestinians, enabling you to thrive and to prosper. “It is a great regret that my time here has been all too short and I pray that one day I shall be able to .”Charlesaposs words of support came as US President Donald Trump was expected to unveil his long-awaited Middle East peace plan.But the initiative, intended to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, is thought to be an unfavourable one for Palestinians, with the Israelis reportedly set to receive territory gains and other concessions.  Charles is due to fly back to the UK this evening after his two day tour of the region which aides said he has enjoyed immensely. The governor of Jerusalem Kamel Hmeid  told the prince how Christians and Muslims had lived for centuries in a peaceful coexistence in Bethlehem, and recounted the story of how Omar was invited to pray inside the Church of the Holy Nativity.  He refused, saying thathe did it would become a mosque and instead he prayed outside.  The Omar mosque is named after the Caliph Omar, who conquered Jerusalem in  but guaranteed that Christians would be free to continue to worship. The message of religious co-existence was, said Charles, a wonderful example. In the afternoon, Charles held a historic meeting with Palestinian president Mahmood Abbas who thanked him and the UK for its support in support for a two state solution.  The Prince beamed as he spoke of his “great joy” at being able to visit the region, adding: “I have been looking forward to this opportunity for nearly  years, therefore visiting Bethlehem is a great joy.” Charles, , said he his visit had made him “even more aware” of the issues and challenged faced by the Palestinian people.  The prince later sampled a range of traditional Palestinian olive-based products on a visit to a convent and monastery in Bethlehem.  Visiting the Carmelite Convent and Sacred Heart Fathers Monastery, which dates back to , the heir to the throne revelled in sharing his interest for conservation with others with the same passion.  He spent over  minutes chatting to conservationist Vivien Sansour, who told him about the key place of olive trees on Palestinian heritage, cuisine and practises.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA self-conscious singer who spent years aposlooking miserableapos claims sheaposs been cured of her aposresting b***h faceapos thanks to dramatic surgery. Paige Dobson, , would try and stop the skin on her chin aposcrease, pull and dimpleapos by keeping her expression neutral. But it left her looking aposconstantly miserableapos and appearing to permanently sport a aposresting b***h faceapos. But her le has been transformed after she underwent a gruelling five-and-a-half-hour operation on her jaw, which included a nose job. The op saw her jaws broken, realigned and secured in place with metal plates and screws. Speaking a year on from the surgery, Paige, from Netheravon, Wiltshire, said: Before my surgery I was so self-conscious and always avoided smiling. I hated having pictures taken and always covered half my face with my hand. Whenever I closed my mouth it would crease up andI laughed too much Iaposd be really gummy, it held me back from enjoying myself and being able to smile nicely in photos. The orthodontist said braces wouldnapost do anything because my overbite was so bad. When we looked back on pictures my mum always used to say aposPaige why have you got a resting b**** face apos She was obviously kidding, but it was from where my mouth was pulling so I constantly looked miserable. I felt it because I looked it - but now all I do is beam in photos. Paige suffered years of ridicule from cruel bullies who imitated the way she laughed and even followed her home from school, with the teen trying to hide her overbite by refusing to smile for pictures.  But since the le-changing surgery, Paige has gained so much confidence she now loves to smile - banishing her  b***h face once and for all. In addition to hating having pictures of herself taken, Paige also had to deal with bullies who mocked her appearance with cruel impersonations. Paige said: When I was  I got bullied to absolute hell. There was a group of people who would always make comments, laugh and impersonate how I would lookI was laughing, it was really cruel.  The main girl in this group got her boyfriend to follow me home from school and shout abuse at me for six months - it was so bad we had to get the police involved. After two-and-a-half years in braces, Paige underwent surgery, known as bimaxillary osteotomy, at Salisbury District Hospital in Odstock, Wiltshire, on January  . Surgeons broke Paigeaposs top and bottom jawbones and fixed her jaw in a new position with plates and screws.  Once theyaposd re-positioned her jaw, doctors realised her nose was off centre so they had to break her septum to be able to realign her nose with her jaw - effectively giving Paige a aposbonusapos nose job. The transformation was so radical that when Paigeaposs mum, -year-old hairdresser Tracey Dobson, walked into the room post-surgery she didnapost recognise her daughteraposs side profile. Paige said: I didnapost come round from the anaesthetic until pm that night.  When my parents came in the room my mum said as she walked towards me she took a step back and went to walk away because she didnapost recognise me as my side profile was already dferent. The operation hasnapost just changed my jaw itaposs changed my nose too - everything is completely dferent. Paige took six weeks off college where she was studying Performing Arts A levels to recover, and at the six-month mark had her braces removed. A year on from the op, Paige says she aposdoesnapost recogniseapos the person she sees in the mirror and feels like le has just begun.

story: NewsMums bananas demand for nanny who can ski, drive in foreign lands and cook veganA Silicon Valley CEOs job advertisement for a nanny, house manager and cook for her twins, , has gone viral over its ambitious requirements for candidatesShareCommentsByTalia Shadwell:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsThe successful candidate is going to have their hands full" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA job ad for a nanny posted by a mum of twins has gone viral after her high standards left some wondering whether even aposMary Poppinsapos would qualy. The Silicon Valley CEO wants a nanny, housekeeper and cook all rolled into one- and she wants them to commit the next five years to looking after her kids. Nannies applying to care for her two ten-year-olds will be required to ski, drive in foreign countries, cook vegan meals, and coordinate overseas holidays for the family. The ad called for a candidate who is CPR-certied, a strong swimmer and leguard, and is a spreadsheet whizz capable of juggling the childrenaposs lives and the housework - all the while tracking budgets and expenses. Twitter user Kimberley Harrington tweeted screenshots of the ad which quickly went viral as people were stunned at the mumaposs ambitious list of requirements.aposLook I know what day it is and where I’m posting this but I still challenge you to find ANYTHING more bananas bat sh*t than THIS. I DARE YOU,apos Harrington wrote.  The ad didnapost identy the CEO or the company she runs in San Franciscoaposs Silicon Valley.However it noted she is based in city Menlo Park, home to the headquarters of countless start-ups and tech giants including Facebook.The job description shared by the CEO included a formidable list of desired qualities. Major responsibilities are keeping the household family and staff and its processes and programs well organized, cooking organic foods that meet our allergy requirements, planning vacations, camps and after school activities, errands, and spending time with the kids,apos the job description reads.   Whoever gets the position will have to agree to a scheduleof five days a week aposapproximately .am to .pm Sunday- Thursdayor Monday-Friday apos. aposMom is a CEO and needs to relax on weekends. Weekends are busy with sports and play dates. Live-in option is the full kitchen, one-bedroom pool house.apos The ad said the CEO was looking for an intelligent multi-tasker with a university degree or equivalent, who will also need to help her children with homework and play maths games with them. An example of a maths game the nanny would be expected to play was included in the ad: aposHow much fish should we buy today for five of us apos  The nanny would also be expected to organise the familyaposs vacations, alongside budgeting and organising the housework using spreadsheet tools. aposConduct research into domestic and global vacation options based on criteria, populate information into a simple Excel spreadsheet, recommend and book vacations, track vacation expenses in Excel including track vacation home deposits getting ed.apos The nanny was also expected to organise the childrenaposs social lives and chores. The ad continued that the successful candidate should be: aposemailing and texting vendors, friends and parents in a professional manner, using Word to track kidsapos chores, plan household meetings, track allowance and household expenses, and monitor and track purchases and make s on timeapos.  The nanny will also be in charge of the household menu, which the ad made clear would be mostly vegan. aposFamily eats organic and is allergic to cow and goat dairy, chicken eggs, green beans and watermelon.apos  The job also required the worker to be a strong swimmer and be a skilled outdoors and sports person. aposCan do short mountain hikes, willing to work out together in the home gym with the mom, can ski, is CPR-certied, excellent driver, experience driving in snow, experience driving in other countries, skilled at coaching kids and has room in their heart to love the kids and the mom.apos  Twitter users reacted with disbelief to the job advert, with some calling it an impossible list of qualications. Others suggested anyone qualied to meet all her requirements deserved a six-figure salary. While another joked they thought the ad was going to end with: This is an unpaid internship.  Naima Cochrane wondered whether the perfect candidate even existed, writing: First of all, this is an actual IMPOSSIBLE list of qualications - literally impossible. Even Mary Poppins didn’t cook family meals. Mom as a CEO should know that. Secondly, I feel terrible for the mom’s support staff at work [because] she’s clearly ridiculous. Brooklyn Ann had another theory, writing: I bet you the mother wrote this to prove a point to her husband when she askedthey could hire help and he probably said something dismissive of her parenting household work like, Fine, but I donapost see why you need any help.

A dramatic video shows chaotic scenes as crowds of people wearing face masks while waiting to be tested fill jam-packed corridors of a hospital in Wuhan, where the virus originated. People who appear to be medical staff are seen in full protective body suits pointing and shouting as they try and make their way through the queues. In a statement, Mr Whitty said: I am working closely with the other UK chief medical officers. title: i sent auschwitz wedding day
story: NewsI was sent to Auschwitz on my wedding day - the Nazis even took my ringIbolya Knill remains bright and resilient as she reflects on the devastating turn her le took - she has told her story as she always promised she wouldshe survivedShareCommentsByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  JAN NewsIby Knill refuses to be shackled by her history " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Teenager Ibolya Knill was wearing bright red high-heeled sandals when she was rounded up by Nazi troops in surprised raids on Jewish homes in Hungary.A week later, the -year-old was to marry, and in the pocket of her carefree summer dress nestled a pair of wedding rings she had just had engraved with the date of their big day: June , . Tragically, that date was to take on a very dferent signicance.For when the morning of June  finally arrived, Ibolya – known as Iby – still wearing her red heels and by now filthy summer dress, found herself crammed “like cattle” into a wagon heading to the notorious death camp Auschwitz in Nazi-occupied Poland.Where there should have been flutters of girlish excitement in her stomach, now there was just a heavy, gnawing sense of dread. There was no way of getting word to her fiancé, Gaspar, and there was no reasoning with the guards. “I went to them and said, ‘Today is supposed to be my wedding day’,” she recalls. “They said it made no dference. I didn’t talk of [Gaspar] again. There were a group of us in the wagon who decided to stick together. But we also decided to talk of nothing from the past, not our families or friends. It was our way of coping. I didn’t tell them.” Monday marks the th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz by Soviet troops. Iby, now , remains bright and resilient as she reflects on the devastating turn her le took. Originally from Bratislava, in what was then Czechoslovakia, she was born to a Jewish mother. After the Nazis invaded, she was smuggled to Hungary, where she lived with non-Jewish family of her father, carrying  documents that stated she was not a Jew. But in March , the Nazis also invaded Hungary. Iby was at the house of a Jewish friend that was raided, and she did not have her fake papers on her. Even with them she would have been in a precarious position, as she had been arrested and interrogated over her involvement in the resistance. She was also frightened of being caught out as an illegal immigrant. She confided these worries in a man she had recently met, Gaspar. He proposed, in the hope Hungarian citizenship would keep her safe.  Iby recalls: “We had only known each other for a matter of days, but I think he fell in love with me. “Under the circumstances, that was enough. People didn’t know what was going to happen to them, and le moved quickly. “He gave me money to buy the wedding rings and to get them engraved.” She would never see Gaspar, or those rings, again. Before she got on the transport to Auschwitz they were stripped from her, along with her earrings. The conditions of her five-day transport were appalling, and by the time she arrived at Auschwitz, exhausted and terried, Iby had every reason to feel utterly crushed. But instead, anger surged. Pushed onto the railway  of the death camp, she linked arms with friends she made during the journey.  Scared and starving though she was, Iby – in her defiant red heels – burst into the Hungarian national anthem, leading the group in song as they walked towards the camp’s notorious Angel of Death, Dr Josef Mengele. This was the man responsible for deciding which of the frailest new arrivals to send straight to the gas chambers. Her act of courage protected her and her new friends. She says: “We didn’t think we had anything to lose, and had been told to look livelywe wanted to live. Mengele laughed – he thought it was funny. I remember him – a very smart chap, with two dogs and two women in unorm behind him. He just waved us on through the gate. I was so angry. And that anger stayed with me. It helped me survive.” After her brush with Mengele, she was pushed into a “huge room”. “They stripped me of everything but my high heels – prisoners kept their shoes – they looked absolutely crazy.”  She is able to laugh a little, despite the horror of the memory. “Prisoners in striped pyjamas came and cut the hair all over our bodies. “We were pushed into showers and dressed in rags.” Iby was not tattooed with a registration number, because the tattooists ran out of ink. She has since found it out:  it remains ingrained in her mind. She was marched to Birkenau, the largest of the sub-camps within Auschwitz, where prisoners were crammed  to a hut. Chillingly, “There was no trees, grass or birdsong,” she recalls. Iby, who now lives in Leeds, West Yorks, has never ed to Auschwitz – and has no desire to ever go back. “I’m told it’s still the same, the atmosphere has stayed the same,” she says. They lived in just two rooms - one containing buckets for toilets and another to sleep in.  “The only way was to lie like spoons, heads on hips,” she says. “You had to fight your way outyou needed to get to the buckets in the night. But you wouldn’t be able to get back in. You’d have to sleep standing by the wall.” The prisoners called the green-flecked soup they were served from buckets ‘grass food’. “But the thirst was worse than the hunger,” she recalls. The only way she and the others knew which day it was, she says, was because once a week they were taken to be showered. The showers were in the same location as the notorious gas chambers – and Iby had no way of knowing to which they would be taken. Worst of all, she explains, was the smell that pervaded the camp. “The whole place smelt of burning flesh,” she says adding that she cannot attend a barbecue to this day.  She had no idea what had happened to her family, until one day a prisoner emptying the buckets told her that her mother was in Auschwitz, and searching for her. They never saw each other in the amp, but were reunited after the war. Later, Iby found out her father had been in Auschwitz, too. “But he was gassed – the very last time the gas chambers were used.” Iby herself left the death camp after “ days and  nights” – still wearing her red heels, with her rebellious spirit burning bright. Pretending to be a nurse, she volunteered for a slave labour transport to another camp, in the hope it would be better. As she waited to be loaded onto a wagon, a teenage girl approached. Iby recalls: “She was a twin. She and her sister and watched their parents go to the gas chambers, and were being experimented on by Josef Mengele. They knew that after that they would die. “She asked me,I survived, to tell the story of Auschwitz. I promised I would.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe mother of a British tourist executed in cold blood has been left devastated and distraught after five men were cleared of his murder. Jeremy Brooke was held down by the armed gang and shot in the chest and face by one of his attackers after trying to protect four of his friends while on holiday in South Africa. The -year-old had leapt onto the back of one of the attackers who had broken into rented Nkanya Lodge in Elliotdale, back in February . The gang pinned him down and fired two bullets into his body, before robbing all five of their mobile phones and laptops. They then escaped the scene of the midnight attack in a car. Qualied emaster and instructor Jeremy - whose widowed mother Marian lives in North Cornelly, Wales - was critically injured and died on the way to hospital. The five men were quickly arrested after the botched robbery in which Jeremy’s four friends were also robbed and assaulted. They were on a ing holiday together at the time. His pals Gregory De Valle, Stephen Boscher, Bradley van Staden and Beila Cook were not seriously hurt, but gave vital evidence to police that led to the suspectsapos quick capture. Jeremy’s mother, his older sister Bronwen and the four friends were today said to be “devastated” after the five men – one of whom is now dead – were found not guilty.  They had been waiting nearly six years to see justice done. Yesterday a close family friend said: It has been delay after delay after delay and finally we had the court case. The evidence was clear cut and Marian is devastated and distraught at the not guilty verdict, but the fight will go on. Judge Buyiswa Majiki, sitting at Mthatha High Court, found them not guilty of murder due to “conflicting evidence” as to who pulled the trigger that fired the two fatal bullets. He did however find all five guilty of robbery with aggravating circumstances, possession of stolen property - which included the stolen car - and possession of firearms. Prosecutor Nomapha Mvanda said he would appeal the ruling and demand a retrial of the five men.  Jeremyaposs e boss Mr De Valle said the five victims were very disappointed”. He added: ”We cannot believe after five years and  months they come to this conclusion. “The accused made confessions to the murder and the evidence was overwhelming so the State must appeal the not guilty and they will win at a retrial as this verdict is incorrect”. Akhona Thornto, Malibongwe Lugalo, Yandisa Masimi and Mkhanyisi Qalingoma were found not guilty along with Sicelo Sigagayi, who was killed in a gangland shooting in . He had been on the run twice after escaping from custody, but was gunned down while on the streets.  The murder case was adjourned for sentencing until January . In the past the victim’s mother Marian had spoken about their fight to get justice for Jeremy – who was known as Gumby. She told the BBC in an interview in  she had spoken to Jeremy the day before he was shot dead and that he was in “good spirits”. Marian said: “He was always travelling but we never went more than two weeks without speaking to me and he used to ring me from anywhere in the world for a chat”. Jeremy was born in Durban to British parents who lived in South Africa for  years.  They moved back to Wales in  due to fears of rising violence in the country. Jeremy’s father had died suddenly just months before he was shot dead leaving Marian a widow and with only one living child remaining. Her son loved to travel and went to agricultural college in Cornwall. Bronwen, a married physiotherapist from Neath, said: “He was lovely and one of those people everyone loved and he touched people’s lives.

title: polar bears extinct trophy hunting
story: NewsPolar bears will be extincttrophy hunting does not end, expert warnsAwarding-winning wildle photographer and conservationist Ole Liodden has warned the iconic Arctic species will die outtrophy hunting is allowed to continueShareCommentsByNada FarhoudEnvironment editor:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsA hunter poses with a dead polar bear" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTrophy hunting of polar bears must be banned or the iconic Arctic species will die out, a conservationist has warned. Not only are the animals battling to survive the impact of climate change, which is melting the ice they need to hunt on, but trophy hunters and a soaring demand for their skins in China are speeding their extinction Awarding-winning wildle photographer and conservationist Ole Liodden, who has spent four years working on a project to highlight their plight, also told how hunters target the healthiest, strongest males, which leaves only the weakest iniduals to pass on their genes. He warned: “We have to stop trophy hunting and the commercial skin trade. “It is the only way polar bears have a chance of survival.” Nearly , polar bears were killed by hunters in the Arctic between  and , the most recent figures available. More than , polar bears have been killed since  – twice as many as today’s remaining population. The figures, much higher than previous estimates, were only brought to light after the Norwegian’s lawyers forced the Canadian government to release them under Freedom of Information laws. Explaining the allure of the species, he told the Mirror: “The polar bear is one of the most exclusive species for trophy hunters to pursue. But it is the mammal species least suitable because of low cub survival, low reproduction rate, and climate change.  “Although a warmer climate may largely determine the future distribution of polar bears, the vast majority of population reductions over the past  years are attributable to unsustainable hunting.” Polar bear trophy hunting started in Alaska, USA, and Svalbard, Norway, in the s, with only a few killed. But the expeditions attracted wealthy clients, who fuelled an industry that soon used planes, helicopters and ships to pursue the bears.Russia banned polar bear hunting in , followed by the USA in  and Norway a year later.  Canada’s Arctic region is now the only place in the world where hunting polar bears is still legal. Liodden says Inuit leaders are against trophy hunting but that the Canadian government encourages them to act as guides for it. Skins can fetch up to £,. Last summer a Daily Mirror investigation uncovered a host of firms offering hunts in the Arctic Circle marketed as “the most memorable” trophy collectors would ever find. For £, the -day hunts include the services of a taxidermist.  The companies proudly boast “% success rates”. There are ,-, polar bears left in the wild, according to the World Wildle Fund. But that number could be cut by two thirds by mid-centurythe Arctic continues to warm, and they are “vulnerable” on the International Union for the Conservation of Nature’s Red List. The Mirror is campaigning for a ban on the cruel trophy industry.

title: callachan aiming to end below par east end record with dark blues
story: East End Park is a venue Ross Callachan is no stranger to.In his six years in the Raith Rovers first-team, he took part in the Fe derby four times, twice in Dunfermline.On neither occasion, however, was the -year-old able to end up on the winning side.But Callachan is hoping to change all that tonight when he heads there as a Dundee player after joining on loan until the end of the season from St Johnstone last week.The Pars are on a poor run of form themselves, losing their last five in the league.However, Callachan insists that counts for nothing and all the Dark Blues can focus on is doing what’s required to earn all three points after the disappointment of exiting the cup to Motherwell in his debut last weekend.“I’ve played them a few times home and away but it’s always tough going to East End,” he said.“They’ll be looking to win, losing their last five games, so I think it’s a must-win for both teams.“It was disappointing to be out of the cup but at least we can focus on the league now.“We have  games left until the end of the season so, hopefully, we can go and push for the play-offs.”Callachan is realistic, however, and knows the pitfalls of the Championship from his time at Raith.With just four points separating Dundee in fourth and the Fers in fth, he hopes to draw on all his experience to help the Dee in this one and every game after.“It’s very tough. I think in this league teams can be inconsistent and, probably, Dundee have been like that themselves throughout this season,” he added.“Hopefully, I can come and help that. I’ve been in the league before with Raith and in the play-offs, too. I’ve been there and done it all before.”Although keen to kick on and help the Dark Blues this term, Callachan is just happy to be playing again after enduring a long spell out of the team at Saints.He only made four appearances for the Perth men this season, the last coming in September, and is enjoying feeling wanted again.“I’m hungry to play, do well and help the team,” he said defiantly.“I want to get games under my belt because it was frustrating at St Johnstone.“You’re sitting in the stands and you feel you can help the team but the manager thought otherwise.“I’m just happy somebody wants me here and I feel like I’ve fitted in right away.“Hopefully, I can go and play and show what I can do.“The initial attraction was Dundee were interested in me. My head was turned right away.“Obviously, not playing at St Johnstone made me want to come here.“The plan is to help the club get to where it wants to be, back in the Premiership.“We’re in the play-off spots now so, hopefully, we push and climb up to second.“Dundee United are going to win the league so the main thing for us is getting to the play-offs and going up that way.“We want to finish as high as possible.”Playing alongside and learning from quality players like Graham Dorrans is another reason why Callachan was happy to make the switch up the A, across Tayside.And he was delighted to see his team-mate sign a new deal this week.“He’s, obviously, played at a right high level and you can tell he’s a good player who can help the team.“Him signing a new deal can only be good for us.“It’s good for everyone we have that competition.“It’s good for the club and for the boys, competition is always good.”

title: dee closing in on wigan wide man ollie crankshaw
story: Dundee are looking to bolster their squad with the loan signing of Wigan youngster Ollie Crankshaw.The -year-old winger is set to check in at Dens Park until the end of the season as Dee boss James McPake seeks to increase his options in wide areas.With Josh McPake and Josh Todd having now left the club, Crankshaw would come straight into the first-team picture – something the Latics are keen for him to do.The Championship side want him to cut his teeth at a higher level with his only previous experience coming in non-league football with the likes of Curzon Ashton, Colne and Clitheroe.Gaffer James, meanwhile, has heaped praise on one man he has already got in on loan – Ross Callachan.The St Johnstone midfielder made his debut in dark blue in the - Scottish Cup loss to Motherwell at the weekend.Despite a poor performance overall, James was happy with his new charge, saying: “He’s really short of match practice but he added a dferent dimension to what we’ve got. I thought he did well.“He got up closer to and beyond Kane .“He’s an old fashioned box-to-box midfielder but he can play as well.“He’ll get on the end of crosses in both boxes and has a real energy about him.“He got longer than I had imagined but he handled it well and I was pleased with him.“He’s a fit lad and is in great nick. He’s been training really hard in the hope of either getting in the St Johnstone team or getting away to play games. He’s desperate to play football.“He’s brought a freshness to the place.”Of any further signings, James added: “We need help in a couple of positions but we’re looking at the summer as well.“We’re trying to add quality and stick to the long-term process we set out at the start.”Meanwhile, former Dundee defender Jack Hendry has checked in at Australian side Melbourne City on loan.Hendry joined Celtic from the Dark Blues in January  after making  appearances and scoring two goals in his time at Dens.

title: everything need know man inspired burns night
story: As Scotland gets ready to celebrate Burns Night , we take a look at the man who inspired the annual celebration, Robert Burns.Robert ‘Rabbie’ Burns was a Scottish poet and lyricist from the s, who is widely regarded as the national poet of Scotland.He wrote more than  poems and songs before his death in .He is best known for his work in the Scottish language and works focusing on political issues and his liberal views.One of his most famous pieces of work is Auld Lang Syne – heard of it In , he was chosen as the greatest Scot by the Scottish public in a vote run by STV.Many people hold Burns suppers on or around Burns Night to celebrate the man in question, and these involve toasting and reading pieces written by Burns.The meal centres on the Scottish speciality haggis, which Burns wrote about in the poem Address To A Haggis.New research has also found that Scotland#s national bard features in more than  road names across the UK.Glasgow has the highest concentration of streets named after Robert Burns with  featuring his name, according to Royal Mail analysis released on the eve of Burns Night.The town of Ayr, near his birthplace of Alloway, has the second highest number with , followed by London on .The Ayrshire village of Mauchline, where he lived for a time, and Greenock in Inverclyde are joint fourth with .Royal Mail said the poet has inspired  street names in total around the UK, with some addresses influenced by his work, people he knew and the food and drink associated with Burns Night..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgm ga ga ga ga ga ga, title: Everything you need to know about the man who inspired Scotland s Burns Night --

title: major shake up of education in dundee to be debated as plans to merge craigie high and braeview academy unveiled
story: A massive shake-up of education provision in Dundee has been unveiled by council leader John Alexander .The far-reaching proposals brought forward by Mr Alexander and his administration would see:Subject to consultation, a new £ million superschool, merging pupils from Braeview and Craigie, could be built at the former St Saviour#s High with a projected opening of .Braeview was ravaged by fire in September . The blaze was described in council reports as #catastrophic# with #around % of teaching rooms signicantly damaged#.Mr Alexander said: #There is a real need for improvement in the east of the city.#We have spent £m since  and invested in new schools and that is not including the £m spent on existing schools.#But we cannot afford to build two brand new schools.#The plan,we get agreement for a full consultation, is to merge Craigie and Braeview Academy.#We are looking at what happened in Fe after a fire when there was a merger with a college. We see this as the way and Dundee and Angus College would be involved in taking this forward, with enhanced provision.#Both these schools are grade C in terms of quality and both need upgrading but looking at the financial elements we cannot afford it.#The priority is in the east and we cannot have Braeview Academy people sitting in portable cabins.#Mr Alexander, a former pupil of St Saviour#s High School, outlined how #vocational partnerships# between Braeview and Michelin would be continued at the new campus at Drumgeith Road.He added that a joint project between Dundee City Council and Dundee and Angus College would be launched to accommodate people with additional support needs.Mr Alexander said: #I spoke with three executives from Michelin and we are really focused on making things work.#The consultation,approved by committee on Monday, would start on February  and run until the end of March. We have to be honest with the public and we want the feedback from parents.#This is the very start of the process. And as a parent your focus is absolutely on what is in the best interests of your children.#Part of the consultation process will be looking at proposals for Craigiebarns to be part of the catchment area for Grove. That would take effect from August , so again there is a lead in time to give people the time to give feedback.#He told how boundaries are to be changed to help accommodate the uneven mix of schools which are under capacity and those which are over capacity both in primary and secondary.Turning his attention to the over side of the city, Mr Alexander said: #The re-alignment catchment areas for Harris Academy would remove Invergowrie and they would go to school in Perth.#Meanwhile, the future of a  much-vaunted new primary is also hanging in the balance — at least in the short-term.The council leader hinted that he understood that was likely to be a controversial decision.#We have also had a very detailed analysis of how many pupils in the area of Western Gateway and which schools they go to,# Mr Alexander continued.#There are  pupils on site , but we need to address the other issues with the priority being at the east end of the city, so Western Gateway is not a priority. This is not the time to do it and we cannot construct a primary school on the basis of  pupils.#We are not saying no to the school, but it is just not the right time now. We understand there is an expectation.#

title: aberdeen man in 16 month wait for operation
story: An Aberdeen pensioner is demanding answers after waiting  months for an operation.Medics found bladder stones in Joseph Ritchie’s body in September  and he is waiting to go under the kne and get them removed.The -year-old from Kingswells is demanding answers from NHS Grampian and said his long wait for the procedure is “not good enough”.According to the health board there is a -week wait for routine gastroenterology surgery.He said: “I just want to get rid of the stones. It is unbelievable.“There’s something happening there that’s working against me.“I don’t know what it is but it is wrong. There is an anxiety as well.“You feel like you’re smashing your head off a brick wall. I don’t get it.“You can put up with a wait of two or three months, but this is just hopeless and not good enough.”Mr Ritchie looks after his we who has fibrosis and he is worried about the impact surgery could have on his role as a carer.He is unhappy about the delay and branded Aberdeen Royal Infirmary the “worst performing hospital” in the country.Mr Ritchie said: “I am my we’s carer, she has fibrosis, and gets worse by the day.“I am trying to be strong for her. I think  months is a long time to wait and I don’t think the listings are being managed properly.“I was assessed for the operation in November and I thought it would be done within a month and a half.“It must be the worst performing hospital in Scotland.”Mr Ritchie said he has been in pain in the past but that has eased recently and he said he is feeling “all right” at the moment.A spokeswoman for NHS Grampian said: “We cannot comment on inidual patients or their course of treatment.“However we can confirm that Mr Ritchie has been in touch with our feedback service and we have responded to the matters he has raised.“If he has further concerns we would encourage him to get back in touch with us directly.“Speaking generally, we do face some challenges around waiting times for a number of specialities.“We are working hard to see patients as quickly as possible and those in most urgent need of treatment are seen as a matter of priority.”

title: aberdeen complete signing of matty kennedy until 2023
story: Aberdeen have signed winger Matty Kennedy from St Johnstone on a three-and-a-half year contract until summer .The -year-old goes straight into contention to make his Dons debut in Sunday#s Premiership trip to St Mirren .Kennedy had already agreed a pre-contract to join the Dons in the summer.However, Aberdeen manager Derek McInnes wanted to secure the Northern Ireland international squad player six months earlier to solve a lack of pace and creativity evident in recent games.Aberdeen pushed through a deal to land Kennedy in the January transfer window  in a deal understood to be for £, plus add-ons.His signing was completed at Pittodrie tonight.Capped at every level from youth to U by Scotland, Kennedy recently switched allegiance to Northern Ireland when called into a recent squad.The former Everton, Kilmarnock and Cardf City play-maker has started  times for Saints this season, scoring five times.Crucially he is not cup tied for the Scottish Cup having missed the defeat of Morton at the weekend due to a knock.Kennedy is the second major signing secured by McInnes during the January window having secured midfielder Dylan McGeouch from Sunderland.Teenage midfielder Mark Gallagher was signed from Ross County but he is for the development squad.Atlanta United attacker Jon Gallagher also extended his loan deal from the American MLS side until the end of the season.

title: a bumper year for rallying
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards was a big year for Argyll locals with the much anticipatedof one of the biggest events in Scotland on the doorstep, Mull Rally, and the continued running of the Mach  Stages and Argyll Stages in Dunoon. Three events all within a stones throw of Mid Argyll.Jamie Miller was the only local to enter this event, starting his Scottish Tarmac Rally Championshipcampaign for the year in the rapid  Citroen CR. Paul Hunter, swapping his pacenotes for spanners, was on hand to assist Jamie throughout the season. Conditions were said to have been tricky as Knockhill has its own micro-climate, which consists purely of rain, wind, snow, ice, wind and wind. Sadly it wasn#t to be at Knockhill for the team with mechanical failure ending their day after stage two.The first closed road event to take place in England, after the approval of closed road rallying for the UK, was the first event for the famousGTi. Unfortunately for Kirsty Mochrie her licence can only be upgraded to stage events from single venue use when she turns , so it was theof the pairing of Innes Mochrie and Paul Hunter to represent Mid Argyll south of the border. The pair, finding the conditions tricky in the narrow lanes after the top seed cars had been pulling mud from verges and ditches, managed to bounce the wee metro over the first loop of four stages until the gearbox had enough on the fth test.Following the cancelling of Inverness# Snowman Rally earlier in the year, this was now first round of the Scottish Rally Championshipfor Dougie Watt and Ian Parker, and it was interesting to say the least. A glance outside in the morning to see about four inches of snow lying on the roof of the MK Escort was a surprise for a start. A very wet and muddy day saw the pair make it to the finish in one piece which is more than can be said for the clutch cable that snapped about one mile into the final stage, however clinching their first class win of the season was the best start to the championship.With Kirsty #Wee Mo# Mochrie in the co-drivers seat in the rapid Corsa of Steven Hay , a fair pace was set by the pair throughout the day sitting as high as th until they unfortunately had to take a split early to save damaging the car. Back out the next stage and still setting a blistering top  pace in the Corsa, including some hang time on both the jumps.Jamie, back out in the fit C, had bad luck once again. This time an overshoot on a square right and a struggle to get the car started again after a stall sadly earned him a stage max on stage two. Still setting top  times on the day he ended nd which was a fair effort when you include a stage maximum time.Ian was out this time with Fraser #Flat oot Fraz# Smithafter winning an entry to the rally at the STRC Awards in January. Flying out the gates and onto their second lap on the first stage then pop, driveshaft burst. Towed in and sorted, both covered in CV Grease, they made it back out for a skid around and on a mission to tear up some old tarmac tyres.The Granite Stages, now held at RAF Leuchars would see Eoghan Anderson make ato the passenger seat for a hurl in the immaculate MK Escort of Martin Murray. Smiling ear to ear all day, with Bill eagerly awaiting histo the service area for the stage report, they finished th overall.Ian was out with Greg Inglisin his fluorescent Orange Lotus Exige and it was eyes on the prize for STRC points for Greg. A clean day saw Greg really getting to grips with the car on some surprisingly fast stages including a tickle of the limiter in fth saw the pair finish third overall.Back together and with the small repairs from the Speyside done it was time for the Furnace MK toto the woods. A steady run over the opening two stages, Dougie and Ian found their feet after the #off# at the Speyside sent them into service lying th. From seeing their overall position they knew they had to get back into it on the next stage, however on the road section to start stage three there was issues selecting gear and the pair decided to call it a day # damage limitation was the right call, as the input shaft was on its last legs.Jamie was back on the pace for this one, setting a th fastest stage time on the opening test. Sitting th overall heading into stage five was impressive given the competition on the day. Bad luck unfortunately, however, was to .Eoghan was again out with Martin in the MK for a blast. Sadly it was an early bath, retired after stage two but again, as always, enjoying every minute while it lasted.The Argyll rally had been known to have rough and challenging stages the previous two years. Not this time. Ian and Dougie couldn#t believe how good the stages were in comparison to previous years, an absolute joy of an event with the Escort not missing a beat all day on its #shakedown# for the big one. Valuable class points added to the scorecard too, with them ending the event nd overall. The rally had struggled with entries this year and will now run in  as a closed road rally, run by Mull Car Club.Team Mochrie were back together for this one in the Mightyagain and Innes was cutting some questionable shapes in the garage, performing his annual Mach rain dance. Taking chunks of time from his first passes of the stages would see them ring the #s neck and clinch th.Jamie#s luck had finally turned, the C singing all weekend and netting him a topper of th overall and th fastest over the final stage too.Duncan Maclean was back in the driving seat with Ian alongside, giving himself and the car a shakedown before Mull. The freshly rebuilt #blue bullet# was looking superb and managed to finish looking just as sweet. A couple of small teething problems were sorted on the day and the new main focus was to have power steering fitted before Mull # poor Dochy lost about a stone over two days with the effort needed to swing the wee pug around the #s and chicanes.In August Dougie and Ian competed on the Vetomies Rally. A national grade event run alongside the WRC Rally Finland event. Three other crews from Scotland also headed over to sample #the fastest rally in the world#. The stages were unbelievable. Fast, cresty, wide, flowing with a brilliantly smooth surface. The whole event was just surreal. The duo finished the event th overall and more importantly the fastest Scottish crew.Once the car had ed from Finland it was quickly jacked up, checked and loaded onto the trailer the same day for the journey north. Due to two DNFson the Speyside and Scottish, Dougie and Ian had to make the trip to be in with any chance of regaining their class lead in the SRC. Ending the day first in the class meant they were heading into the final round with the lead.Jamie was back out for another counting round of the STRC. Enjoying his day and pushing the wee C on in the blistering heat netted Jamie and co-driver Ian Mccullochrd overall. He must have been relaxed in the heat as in between stages he was off with the overalls and on with the baby lotion, topping up the tan.Ian was back out with Greg in the Lotus. Another fantastic drive from Greg, finishing ninth with the championship title race firmly the primary goal.The final round for the MK and an important one # a DNF here could see Dougie and Ian losing the class lead in the championship. A battle with their rival who they had been chasing all season, Paddy Munro, would come down to the last stage, as the pair were six seconds down on Paddy heading into the final test. Probably one of the duo#s best stages all year, the final push to claim the class honours came down to the finish of the last stage on the last rally of the year. One second! They had taken the class win and the championship.The first event this year for Craig Callander and son Ross would see them prepare Craig#s gravel spec Subaru Impreza at the last minute to take on their favourite event. The #Japanese Tractor# was a fair handful, a light steering alignment issue and a boost problem gave the pair some trouble although finishing th overall made up for the hassle. A fair result given Craig#s absence from tarmac for four years.Returning from the shed with his freshly painted Sunbeam was Alister Macarthur, this time with Claire Tilleyalongside. The freshly fettled #beam was looking and sounding good # crossing the finish th overall after two years out of the seat.Dochy and Ian were back out in the #blue bullet.# All was going well until they had a spin coming over a crest into a square left, losing the bumper and damaging the gear linkage. They managed to get the car back to the end of the Saturday afternoon leg to repair the gear linkage and almost stole the yellow bumper from the recce car until some legends appeared with the duo#s bumper in the back of their Land Rover. Back out onto the  mile #long one# on Saturday night and they had an issue # after a heavy landing over a crest the rear shocker bolt broke, making the car a handful to keep in a straight line. They had to finish another two stages before they could make it back to service, so a finish was all they wanted at this point # th overall and Dochys fourth finish in a row on Mull.Without doubt the driver to watch was Innes and his newly acquired co-driver Lewis Grfiths . The Mightywas spotted airborne at any chance, with the hydro can suspension screaming for a break at each service halt. It was almost all over as the nearside cv joint sheared and the car took a wild turn to the left # both Innes and Lewis thought they would end up IN the Belachroy pub. They managed to make it over the Lochs to the end of the final stage, claiming st overall.Eoghan was back out with Martin to settle the score from the DNF at the summer stages. Sadly a stage maximum time on stage two scuppered their chances of the overall result they were hoping for, however they did set some impressive times, clocking a th fastest time on the final stage.Jamie, back out for the final round of the STRC, was looking to continue his good run from the Pendragon and set a seventh fastest time on stage three in the extremely wet and tricky conditions. Trying to get his money#s worth from his entry fee Jamie, however, decided to take an extra couple of miles on the penultimate stage. Still, the C ran well all day and the conditions suited the car perfectly.Ian was back out with Greg and this time he was aiming to become the Scottish Tarmac Rally Champion for . They set off with five cars in the same class and they had to win the class to get Greg the honours. Setting the pace early they were leading throughout the event. Finishing the event first in their class and third overall meant the job was done # Greg claimed the championship win.The last event of the year saw Kirsty back in the co-drivers seat, gaining even more experience on her path to upgrading her licence. Some typical Knockhill weather was in store as Kirsty had her first taste of RWD rallying in the Mazda MX of Paul Sheard. Kirsty guided Paul around the very wet stages to claim th overall and some valuable points on the board for Paul#s Motorsport News Championship campaign.Special thanks to Alasdair MacConnell who has travelled many miles to don an orange bib and stand in the rain, wind and heat, all to show his support and play a vital part in any event. And to Gavin #Top Tog# Brown, who has been an avid rally man for years and continued to watch us all through the lens, capturing some of our most heroic moments. was a busy year, with a few of us still tinkering away in sheds.  will hopefully see theof Ally and Del Galbraith in their #new# MK Escort and Donald Bowness in the giant killing Nova making aafter some time out.PICS:Dougie Watt and Ian Parker flying in Finland before winning in Aberdeen Photo: Jii Pihlaja. no_a_RallyFinlandFather and son duo Craig and Ross Callendar came in th overall at this year#s Mull Rally. Photo: West Coast Photography. no_aMullRally_CraigCallanderEuan Thorburn took a drama filled Argyll Rally victory, adding to his  win on the event. Photos: Eddie Kelly Motorsport Photography. no_aargyllrallyInnes Mochrie, Lochgilphead and Lewis Grfiths finished Mull Rally st overall. Photo: West Coast Photography. no_aMullRally_InnesMochrie

title: science matters the future for organ donation
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowPresently around , people in the UK are waiting for organ transplantation. All have end-stage organ failure, be it kidney, liver, lung or heart, and require a le-saving transplant.Organs for transplant usually come from bodies of people who agreed to donate before death. But as this does not produce enough organs, both Scotland and England plan to bring in an #opt out# system, meaning that on death a person#s agreement to organ donation is assumed unless they had actively opted out.Live donation is an alternative to awaiting a cadaveric organ. As people can live happily with one kidney or half a liver, family members or altruistic iniduals sometimes offer to donate these organs. Since matching donor and recipient tissue-type, however, is generally required these donations are not always acceptable.Now groups of tissue-type incompatible donor recipient pairs are getting together to mix and match, producing duos who are tissue-type-compatible. So let#s say Annie is rejected as a kidney donor for her sister Jean for incompatibility reasons, and similarly, Arthur is rejected as kidney donor for Jim. But pairing donor Annie with recipient Jim and Arthur with Jean could lead to two successful transplants. A recent report from the US describes the first ever bi-organ exchange involving a liver-kidney swap * .In this specic case a daughter wished to donate a kidney to her mother with renal failure but was rejected because she might later develop the same kidney problem. So she offered half of her liver in exchange for a kidney for her mother. Another donor was eventually identied who wanted to donate half her liver to her sister with liver failure but was rejected because her liver was too small. But she was cleared for kidney donation. So on the day of the swap four operations took place and two needy people received le-giving new organs.Although not presently being considered in the UK, with the ethical issues sorted, this multi-swap procedure opens the way for extended chains of donors and many more lives saved.*Torres et al Am J transplant. :-.

of the James Watt Dock in Greenock around  and SB Archibald Russell being towed by the Steel and Bennie Limited tug Warrior on the Firth of Clyde around .Nicola Scott, exhibitions and events officer at the Scottish Maritime Museum, said: #Window on the Clyde: Family Photos of the River#s Golden Age beautully reflects the pleasure, innovation and tragedy of a bygone era on the Clyde, from the title: eco group in mid argyll helps flush away poverty
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowArdrishaig Church Eco Group is helping provide people with access to a safe loo, clean water and hygiene education as it raises funds for the Toilet Twinning charity.One in three people worldwide currently do not have somewhere safe, private or hygienic to go to the toilet, with many having to go out into fields and areas of bushland.As a result, people are deprived of the dignity of having access to a proper toilet, leading to health problems, often causing them to be unable to work or attend school.Lack of access to clean water and proper sanitation traps people in poverty. Their health suffers and the prospect of developing economically remains out of reach. For women and young girls, the consequences can be even worse, with many being attacked and raped when they use outdoor spaces.
